comments.commentBody: As a transplanted New Yorker, residing in Albuquerque, I frequently visit the Coyote Cafe on day trips to Santa Fe. The atmosphere can't be beat, and the menu items are affordable, innovative, and delicious!!

Getting back to the subject of Toni's post . . .

"Can you argue with Dave Krieger’s point in The Denver Post?"

Yes, I believe so, b/c it is NBC's prerogative to select the game, part of the rights paid for to do SNF. No?
What is the NFL supposed to do, insist on a pre-fixed sched so the last broadcast might be a dud, as used to happen?
What is NBC paying for?
The League should only allow flexing of certain games to prevent "manipulation"??

Don't get Krieger's point, or this thread.

Final score: UF 51, Cincy 24. Thanks for coming...

SEC rules once again.
We had no problem with recent order, ordered a customized laptop on 11/22 received it on 12/1 - must have been the spike in orders after Thanksgiving.

The h1b is hired to do a task and is mostly just that, a task worker. They have little or negative incentive to be creative with applying their knowledge to a problem. Don't blame the h1b for this, it is either a cultural thing, or a legitimate fear of the consequences of failing and getting fired and never having the opportunity to try again. They are happy to say 'yes' and let the people who hired them tell them what to do even if those asking do not know what they are talking about. Language barriers excluded, this scenario is still very common. The h1b doesn't realize that their work isn't the end result, rather, the middle, and they must ask the right follow up questions. This advise applies to everyone. The more quickly you master it the better off you will be.
The nay-sayers here are mostly correct, but those that say, "IT sucks, be an Investment Banker" are only soured by IT because the $ didn't pan out for them. IT isn't for everyone. More troubling is the typical IT person is introverted and will never represent the management majority therefore can expect to be second fiddle. Companies 'like' (g) are changing this and it scares those at the top. Believe me - anyone without a solid understanding of what computers/networks can do and the understanding to make them do it will eventually be outsourced by those that can.

@6, You are spot on when it comes to Dell stuffing the channel!  Think 1999... As for the SEC, they are very sleepy on the ranch, but will come to shareholders rescue only after Dell posts earnings and the accounting irregularities that will follow....

Here's to Ballmer getting fired in 2010 and the stock breaking even (maybe) after the firing hoopla and Gates return to right the ship.  BTW, Apple will overtake MSFT in market cap value in 2010 becoming the largest and most valuable SW company worldwide!

"Companies like Evernote are paving the way, but expect to see more entrepreneurs and start-ups vying to supplement our gray matter with silicon."

Evernote is a nice start, but is a relatively closed system. It has limited sharing and collaborative features. It just seems stuck in web 1.0, even though the rest of the world has become a vibrant, social exchange of knowledge. Check out MemCatch, which provides Evernote-like functionality on the collection side, but it lets you do it in groups and share your knowledge collected throughout the major social networks. It doesn’t have the mobile or client-side apps yet, but those will be here soon. We are still in very active development, so if you want to see some features and suggest them through the pop-out feedback form on the site, we’ll probably add them!

I work in the technology industry and use this stuff for work everyday. While new toys are always nice, I'm finding little use for this stuff in the real world outside the city center. Cell coverage is still too poor where I live, a paltry 75 mi from Manhattan, to consider dropping the landline. The economics of a $50/mo internet still baffle me. Maybe using ooma or some of the newer tech's make it worthwhile, but basically a a cable based phone line is just barely competitive. As for cool location based services, I'll stick with asking the internet at home what's available first so I don't waste my time wandering around to questionable destinations.
Maybe someday the interconnected world will work outside the city center, but right now it leaves a lot to be desired. Apple and the like simply assume everyone has a limitless bankroll for 3-G networks and internet, while the reality is that in the US anyway, these services are overpriced and under perform other countries.

I ordered an XPS 8000 on 11/24. My delivery date changed from 12/14 to 1/5 to 1/19.  Customer service was absolutely useless. I heard several different contradicting excuses as well as spending hours on hold or beng passed around from agent to agent which was eerliy similiar to my experience trying to order the computer. I have been a lifelong Dell customer ordering at least 5 systems previously not to mention LCD tv's and accessories. I cancelled my order on 12/30 and contacted HP, got a better deal and shipping time is a week. No more Dell's in my household!

The great untapped tech opportunity lies in using technology to dissolve cultural boundaries instead of deepening tribalism. Every major international story will be reported simultaneously from both sides of the issue.

The result will still be imperfect. But it will create a new genre of reporting, midground news. News will escape the filters of home cultures and attempt to work from the space between cultures.

The New York Times already puts out at least two versions of the news - the milquetoast global edition and the regular American edition. Its penchant for reporting the American side will yield to a global readership that wants news in the round.

If it fails to yield, it will go out of business. The more inclusive it becomes, the more it will succeed. It could then become the world's newspaper of record. God knows, we need one!

Some will find this deeply threatening. They can always read their local rags, including USA Today or the Philadelphia Inquirer. The New York Times was never meant for them. Murdoch was.

Some changes in the physical format of newspapers, digital or print, will occur. The controversial international stories, for instance, will inevitably be presented as parallel narratives in adjacent columns. The stories about Pakistan and "Islamic extremism," if the future were here today, would have reporters from Pakistani English dailies like the Dawn, the News, or the Nation contributing. The New York Times would provide the forum and the credible brand under which their stories would run... with those of US reporters covering the State Department, the White House, the CIA and so on.

This is not so strange. It is already happening in research and scholarship, for instance. Three people from three different corners of the world are working on a project. My wife is one of them. She is Hindu, Brahmin, Indian, American. The other researcher is Jewish and American. The third scholar is Turkish, Muslim and American. None are limited so far as I know by the circumstances of their birth; all have joined in a common endeavor to find the truth.

In time, all of this will make us less righteous about our cultures, our nations and lessen our appetite for conflict. In that, lies the seed of a radical change, the creation of a post-national world. The New York Times if it is bold enough to own this market can lead the way.

Siddhartha Banerjee
Oxford, Pa

I ordered a new imac and received it 5 days BEFORE the promised
delivery day. Just saying.

Continuing loss of privacy, with attendant risks to civil liberties and personal freedom. The UK is a leader in this trend, as their Orwellian surveillance society becomes more and more capable of tracking everyone in London at all times, mostly in the name of protecting people from terrorists.

Companies such as InfoUSA have developed massive databases that include information on almost everyone. Online sites such as USSearch, 123people, and intelius.com build comprehensive personal profiles from public records and web searches. If you haven't ever done so, you should do a search on yourself from one of these sites.

Large Internet companies have also built extensive profiles of our online behavior. Of course, many of us willingly surrender much of our privacy by posting personal information on the Web. When you add in geolocation, it's becoming easier and easier for those with sufficient resources to learn about you and find you. This is a great development for identity thieves and stalkers, but not so good for the rest of us.
This innovation is not just limited to NYU and Touchco. There is incredibly innovative research happening in this area at Texas A & M University.

This Christmas, I could not tolerate my 5 year old laptop anymore, nor could I resist the siren song of really inexpensive Christmas specials for a new one. I bought an HP Pavilion Entertainment PC Laptop with a 17.3" screen. The price I purchased it at did not include a TV tuner, so I also got a USB HP TV Tuner. OMG! The picture is almost 3-D. I can rewind or record with HP MediaSmart software, though the program crashes alot. I AM throughly entertained. After a couple of weeks, I did turn on the old (20 + years) set. I only confirmed that I will probably put it away or donate it. The laptop screen is almost as large as the old set, but the picture is unbelievable. Sound is not a good through the laptop. And even though I can switch back and forth to other content, like the web, on the laptop I tend to only do one thing at a time, while with the old set I did both. I would like to go back an get the chip installed for TV so that my new laptop will only need an antenna instead of the USB stick, so it will be less like the borg my old laptop had become. Also, TV on the laptop drains power and runs hot.

PS I will only spring for over the air broadcast TV. And note that where I live FOX is available only through over the air Analog, or Cable or Satellite. I am a huge House fan, but I am not a Football fan. House is availabe on HULU. Cable channels should pay a provider more for premium content, or over the air broadcast should open up more channels so that more cable channels aren't saddled to a cable provider.

It would have been impossible to predict on Jan 1, 2000 that Facebook, the iPod / iPhone, Wikipedia, and Youtube would be just around the corner and have such a huge impact. In fact whatever pundits were predicting in 2000 as having a huge impact in the coming decade was likely trivial compared to the unanticipated things just listed.

Why think this coming decade will be any different?
Mostly, this was a list of the challenges that these companies currently face, without predicting how they'll address those challenges. This article is poorly named.

What do I think will be big in the year 2010?

Disappointment over absurdly hyped mobile "breakthroughs" and the ever absent "semantic web".

The web is semantic in the same sense that a thermostat is semantic. In other words, it isn't.

To echo the digital snake oil salesmen: "I'm really excited".

The ladies are forced to put on the wrong identity, they must look suducive and the men lie about there where from and their ages. example is the Philippines tagged website those girls are ready  and desparate to get any man they are so suducive and very sexual very young and put the wrong pictures in their profiles. Please, investigate.
I stopped buying Dell four years ago because they could not timely deliver a PDA and Camera I ordered.  Its amazing they are still in business.

Praise of Wikipedia is unearned.  It is extremely difficult to correct misinformation and outright lies when posted on Wikipedia.  In one instance I attempted to correct  false information wherein an athlete stated he  was an Olympic Team member, when in fact, as a coach of that team I knew he was not.  Moreover he deleted the name of a fine athlete who was.   Any attempt to correct this egregious error has been rebuffed.  Wikipedia...bunch of junk.

Apple should drop the AppleTV and concentrate on offering Mac Minis configured for media use or options making it easy to order one that way directly from Apple.

By the way, I think Oprah's adoption of Twitter was an inflection point too; just not necessarily a good one.

As for Sprint, the only people I know who like and/or defend Sprint are those who have legacy SERO plans, for which they pay next to nothing for whopping amounts of minutes, texts, data, etc. I'd like Sprint too if I paid $30/month for 500 minutes of talk time, unlimited texts, unlimited data, etc. No wonder why they don't make money. And don't expect me to sign up with Sprint, knowing that I'm subsidizing these other people.

As a CPA, I have supported clients in Austin who were Dell employees. Many of those individuals watched as their jobs were shipped overseas or downsized with the elimination of the stellar testing and support Dell formerly provided. If Dell no longer supported those individuals that served as my client base, then I see no reason to support them. That is why I have identified local companies that build, test, and provide support in localities that I service and have also included in my practice some MacBook Pros for possible migration of services.
Please read the Giver, by Lois Lowry, which details a society's life when it gives up being the holders of it's own memories.
@ #5:  Yeah, and you spent between $600-$1000 more than you needed to by buying that Mac.  Thanks for sharing.
